description: From Middle French descourager (modern French décourager), from Old French descouragier, from des- and corage. Surface analysis dis- +‎ courage.

verbs.description: discourage (third-person singular simple present discourages, present participle discouraging, simple past and past participle discouraged) (transitive)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To extinguish the courage of; to dishearten; to depress the spirits of; to deprive of confidence; to deject.
examples: Don't be discouraged by the amount of work left to do: you'll finish it in good time.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To persuade somebody not to do (something).
examples: Discourage litigation. Persuade your neighbors to compromise whenever you can.
